title: man walks london birmingham week
story: Man walks from London to Birmingham in a week for a laugh and not for charityDavid McEntee loved to confuse people who asked him where he was heading to after the -year-old did the brutal -mile walk from London to Birmingham just for funDavid McEntee wasnt raising money for charity - he just did the mega walk for a laugh Image: David McEnteeByFinn ByrneSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | comments A man who walked from London to Birmingham inside a week aposfor a laughapos says he has finally realised a childhood dream. David McEntee, , explained that it has always been at the back of his mind to attempt the mega trip, MyLondon report.He walked along the Grand Union Canal from its start point in Little Venice all the way up to the Midlands where it ends. The hiking enthusiast says the  mile-walk was worth it - even though he wasnapost raising money for charity, like most others who attempt such expeditions. He videoed the whole journey and says it was a trip he has wanted to tackle since he was a youngster. He said: “People would ask me… ‘Where are you off to ’ To which I would reply ‘Birmingham!’ and laugh at their astonished reactions. ‘Thataposs a few hundred miles away isn’t itapos   “Ever since I was a child I was fascinated by the Canal. I decided I would walk the whole route from end to end. I did it to satisfy that childhood wonder for the canal, I did it to get to know an area that I perceive to be in my back garden - and I did it to satisfy my cravings for an adventure! “A highlight of the London section was passing ‘Paradise fields’ which are aptly named. Full of massive trees and a whistling population of birds, this stretch was beautul and extremely peaceful. For a good  minutes I completely forgot I was in London.  He is now turning his skills to building out his own UK Adventure  hiking focused YouTube channel. He continued and said: “Passing by hundreds of Canal boats, I was surprised to be regularly waved to as I walked by its dwellers. I even started ing the greetings to other Canal walkers. “After I had left the hustle and bustle of Warwick Avenue and - Everyone I passed by seemed to be on a similar walking for fun jolly.  Frequented by dog walkers, couples, young families and the occasional commuter I felt safe throughout the entire London Section - and for the rest of the walk to Birmingham. “There is a real sense of community along the canal, the fitness fan added. I think that it can be attributed to a combination of the friendly people who live there, the pleasant and smiling walkers who explore the toe path - and down to its historic and wholesome background.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON YouTube" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news meghan-markles-bond-queen-before-"The corgis loved her Prince Harry on moment Meghan met The QueenByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | comments The most influential royals have been revealed - and itaposs Meghan Markle that takes the top spot, closely followed by the Queen. The two women were introduced when Meghan started dating the monarchaposs grandson, Prince Harry.And at first, the two women struck up a sweet bond with their shared love of dogs and attended an engagement together. But after less than two years as a working royal Meghan - along with Harry - stepped down from The Firm, with the pair leaving the UK for America. Since she left in , Meghan has yet toto the UK and the Queen has yet to meet her new great-granddaughter Lilibet. Here we look back at the early stages of their relationship and where it is at now... Joining the family It was in November  when it was officially announced that Meghan would be joining the Royal Family following her engagement to Prince Harry. To mark the event, both Harry and Meghan gave an interview, where Meghan talked about her first meeting with the monarch lavishing her with praise. She said: Itaposs incredible, I think, you know, to be able to meet her through [Harryaposs] lens, not just with this honour and respect for her as the monarch, but the love that he has for her as his grandmother, all of those layers have been so important for me so that when I met her I had such a deep understanding and of course incredible respect for being able to have that time with her. And weaposve had a really – sheaposs – sheaposs an incredible woman. Love of dogs Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.In the same interview, Harry revealed how his grandmotheraposs love of dogs is something she shares with Meghan.And on meeting her for the first time, the corgis gave Meghan their seal of approval. He explained pointing at Meghan: The corgis took to you straight away. For the last  years, I’ve been barked at, and this one walks in, absolutely nothing, just wagging tails. And Meghan added that the dogs were just laying on my feet during tea, it was very sweet. Christmas privilege  Another sign that the Queen had a sweet bond with Meghan was at Christmas in .In what appeared to be a break with tradition, the Queen gave Meghan the rare privilege of joining the royals for Christmas at Sandringham - even though she had not officially joined the family through marriage.That year, she was pictured with the royals walking to church for their annual Christmas Day service along with her now brother and sister-in-law the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. In contrast and despite being engaged to Prince William at Christmas , Kate had to wait until , once she had married, before being afforded an invitation to Sandringham. First outing  In June , just a month after her wedding, Meghan went on her first official trip with the Queen. They travelled overnight by royal train to Chester, where they spent the day at a number of engagements. Meghan later recalled what happened on that trip during her bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey. She said that after enjoying breakfast on the royal train with the Queen, Her Majesty gted her some beautul pearl earrings and a matching necklace. Meanwhile Meghan also said: We were in the car going between engagements. And she has a blanket that sits across her knees for warmth, and it was chilly. And she was like, aposMeghan, come on,apos and put it over my knees as well... And it made me think of my grandmother, where sheaposs always been warm and inviting and and really welcoming. Oprah fallout Following their move to the United States, in March this year, both Harry and Meghan sat down for a tell-all chat with Oprah Winfrey, where they made several claims against the royal family.Meghan alleged that there had been conversations about how dark son Archieaposs skin would be. She also shared that she had suffered from suicidal thoughts and claimed that she was denied help for her struggle. Following the airing of the chat, it prompted Buckingham Palace to issue a statement from the Queen saying she was saddened by the allegations, but added that some recollections may y. Lilibet tribute After the Oprah interview, the rt between Meghan and Harry and the rest of the royals seemed increasingly large. But when Meghan gave birth to a daughter in June, her name was a sweet tribute to the Queen. She was named Lilibet after an affectionate nickname given to the Queen by her grandfather George V, after she had trouble pronouncing Elizabeth as a child. The Mirror understands the Queen was “never asked” formallythe name could be used, but is supportive of the couple’s choice of name.UK    Since moving to the United States, Meghan has yet toto the UK to see the Queen, who no longer travels abroad due to her age. Her Majesty has not seen great-grandson Archie since  and is yet to meet Lilibet. It’s unclear when Harry and Meghan will bothto the UK with their children, with some tipping them to come to Britain for the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee next year.And speaking in the Channel  documentary : The Queen’s Terrible Year, royal expert Camilla Tominey says it has been hard for the Queen to be so far away from her two great-grandchildren. She said: It is dficult for the Queen. She has not been able to see Archie.  I think the last time she was able to see Archie in the flesh was November . The only way the Queen will be able to see these children isthey come over to the UK. Maybe she will see them next year when she marks her Platinum Jubilee. We have to wait and see.Last week it was reported that the Queen waslooking forward to Christmasandher traditional family festive get togetherat her Norfolk estate of Sandringham. But one report has claimed Harry and Meghannot be coming to the UKto jointhe Queenfor her first Christmas without the latePrince Philip .The couple had reportedly been invited to join the rest of the royals at Sandringham for Christmas.But a source toldPage Six: “There’s a lot that goes into the logistics and the planning of the family Christmas, so of course, staff know that Harry and Meghan are not coming.“If they were, they would have communicated it to their family by now. “But this is Her Majesty’s first Christmas without her husband, so one would have hoped they would want to be with her.” The Sussexes have not commented on the claims. news uk-news mum-shares-new-photos-arthur-"Arthur Labinjo-Hughes: Emma Tustin jailed for le for murderByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The biological mum of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, murdered by his stepmother, has shared new images of the adorable and tragic little boy in tribute to her light of her le son.Olivia Labinjo-Halcrow, , said details of her six-year-old boyaposs abuse and death at the hands of his dad and his ex-girlfriend were harrowing and incomparable.Tustin was found guilty of murder and sentenced to le imprisonment - she will have to serve a minimum of  years before she is eligible for parole.Her former partner and Arthuraposs father, Hughesapos was found guilty of sentenced to  years in jail. Arthuraposs biological mum, who was jailed for  years earlier this year after fatally stabbing partner Gary Cunningham at her Harborne flat in February , paid tribute from her cell in a touching statement read by her own mother.Madeleine Halcrow read her daughteraposs poignant tribute, saying: Arthur was the light of my le. He wasnapost just my only child - he was my best friend.Never did I imagine he would be taken from this world so early in his le. If Arthur could ask for one last thing, it would be that he was remembered for his superpower. That will always be what I remember and Arthuraposs superpower was his smile. Talking about Arthuraposs loves would not be complete without mentioning superheroes, Marvel or DC. Arthur loved them all, from Batman to Black Panther, Aqua Man to the Flash. He had every costume and action figure and would spend hours dressing up and pretending he had all of their superpowers.  Labinjo-Halcrow said that, following the verdicts in the trial of Hughes and Tustin, she wanted to take the opportunity to focus on the le Arthur lived and to celebrate the beautul little boy I knew and loved deeply.Her touching tribute came after Tustin was jailed for le with a minimum of  years after being found guilty of murder and Hughes, guilty of manslaughter, jailed for  years. Twisted Tustin was pregnant with Hughesapos baby when she violently attacked Arthur in June , before undergoing an abortion at  weeks.During the trial at Coventry Crown Court, it has been revealed Tustin tried to avoid justice for her sickening attack on the little boy by taking an overdose and trying to hang herself.Mary Prior QC described her as a “high suicide risk”, saying that she had been “obliged to terminate a pregnancy .  Today, cowardly Tustin refused to leave her jail cell to take to the dock for sentencing. Horrying details in court described how Arthur was segregated for  hours a day and forced to sleep on the floor or in the hallway. Tragic footage also showed Arthur attempting to put away his own duvet in the dark after waking up on the floor. Other sickening evidence described how he was weakened by salt poisoned and deprived of food and water. He was found to have  injuries all over his body after being hit, slapped, kicked, punched, and beaten. Prosecutors said the pair kept Arthur isolated in the home, starved, dehydrated and routinely beaten. Tustin claimed Arthuraposs fatal head injury was self-inflicted, possibly by throwing himself down the staircase in her hallway, where he was forced to spend  to  hours a day, the court heard.  During his evidence, Hughes said Tustin mentally abused and gaslighted him into complying with the punishing disciplinary regime, but also admitted lying to school staff who were checking on Arthuraposs progress during the first Covid- lockdown. Tustin accused Hughes of being violent towards his son on multiple occasions and said he once threatened to throw the boy out of the window. Arthur was screaming and Tom shouted at him. He said apos you donapost shut your f****** mouth Iaposm going to throw you out the windowapos, she said. Arthur said aposno daddy not the windowapos. Tustinaposs barrister Mary Prior QC said: He was going to die and he was going to die because Thomas Hughes was in charge of Arthuraposs le and Arthuraposs le consisted of nothing other than misery. It emerged at trial that Arthur had been seen by social workers just two months before his death, after concerns were raised by his paternal grandmother Joanne Hughes, but they concluded there were no safeguarding concerns. In her victim impact statement, which she read in court ahead of the sentencing, Ms Hughes said Arthur, as a happy, contented, thriving seven-year-old would be alive today had her son not met Tustin. The secondary school teacher added: It is also clear that Arthur was failed by the very authorities that we, as a society, are led to believe are there to ensure the safety of everyone.  An independent review is now under way into the authoritiesapos contact with Arthur before his death. That work will include examining other potential missed opportunities to intervene, including an anonymous call Tustinaposs own stepfather John Dutton claimed in court to have made to social services, and contact with the police from Hughesapos brother about Arthuraposs bruises. The Independent Office of Police Conductis set to publish a report into West Midlands Policeaposs contact with the case, in due course, but has said it found no indication any inidual behaved in a manner that justied disciplinary proceedings. As the sentencing began Mr Justice Mark Wall QC said Tustin had been brought to court for her sentencing but had refused to come up to the dock. Instead he addressed his remarks to Hughes and Tustinaposs empty chair. It also emerged during the hearing how Tustin twice made attempts to take her own le during the trial which jurors were previously told had been periodically delayed for health reasons.  Mr Justice Wall started by saying the trial had been without doubt one of the most distressing and disturbing cases I have had to deal with, adding neither Hughes not Tustin had shown any remorse. The judge said Arthur had been, at the time Tustin was introduced into his le, a healthy, happy young boy. But less than three months after moving in with Tustin at the start of the first national lockdown, the little boy was left broken from exposure to a campaign of acute or prolonged abuse, he said. Tustin was also convicted of two counts of child cruelty, including salt-poisoning and withholding food and drink from Arthur. She had admitted two other cruelty counts, wilfully assaulting Arthur on three occasions and isolating him, including by forcing him to stand in the hallway for up to  hours a day as part of a draconian punishment regime. title: mums horror elf shelf plan
story: Exclusive: Mum’s horror as Elf on the Shelf plan spectacularly backfires and ruins wooden floorThe naughty Elf on the Shelf ruined mum-of-three Lyndsey Sahotas real wooden floor after they sprayed "Were back" to mark theiron December The elves were busy on their first night backByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA mum who wanted to surprise her children on December  with theof her familyaposs naughty Elf on the Shelf was gutted when the little creatures created more chaos than she was expecting. Lyndsey Sahotaaposs three children Bella, , Jaxon,  and Carter,  raced into the kitchen to find their advent calendars with their three elves, who had started a fight with flour. But alongside the flour the beauty technician from Swindon, Wiltshire had also written Weaposre back on the floor with snow spray and flour. The -year-old started clearing the mess as her children tucked into breakfast and soon started panicking when she realised it wasnapost coming off. The snow spray had been absorbed into her wooden floor and left a permanent mark. * Have you had an Elf on the Shelf disaster  Email webnews@mirror Speaking to the Mirror Lyndsey said: This was the first one of the year and the first in our new home, we only moved in eight months ago. The wooden floor was new when we moved in, but our old house had white tiles on the floor, so everything would wipe off. Iaposm gutted, I just didnapost think about the floor. I was using up the dregs of a snow spray can Iaposd been using on decorations and when it ran out I added the flour. She added: I was shouting, itaposs not coming off. Not wanting to ruin the fun for her children, she quickly blamed the elves for the mess.Lyndsey uploaded the images to a Mrs Hinch fans page on Facebook where people help out by suggesting how to clean up ious problems.She added: I put the post on the Facebook group and Iaposve had so many messages with people saying try dferent things. One person said Iaposd spelt it wrong, but that was the least of my worries. Iaposve even had people message to say their husband is a carpenter and I should try this. Unfortunately so far none of the suggestions have worked and the family may have to replace the entire floor. But Lyndsey added that she wonapost give up trying to make this time of year magical for her children. Iaposm gutted, but I do see the funny side of it. Iaposm always up for all the kids stuff like that. Last night the three elves had a baby so we have another to look after now. title: mum who keeps christmas tree
story: Exclusive: Mum who keeps Christmas tree up all year round shows off stunning monthly designsWhile most will only go up for a few weeks, Vicki Morley’s Christmas tree has stayed since last December and it’s been redecorated  times with a brand new themeVicki, , who lives in Derbyshire, told how the tree-athon began for an emotional reason Image: Pete JenkinsByEimear OHaganAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsReal or articial, big or small, festooned with tinsel or ­baubles, the tree is the star of the show when it comes to Christmas decorations.But while most will only go up for a few weeks, Vicki Morley’s has stayed since last December. And it’s been redecorated  times, with a brand new theme. The mum-of-four said: “Usually my tree comes down in January. But these are unprecedented times, so this year I’ve kept the tree up   in our living room.” Vicki, , who lives in ­Langwith, Derbyshire, with husband Darren, , sons Niall, , -year-olds Dexter and Lennon and daughter Niamh, , told how the tree-athon began for an emotional reason.She added: “Last Christmas my brother Steven, , spent  days in hospital, including in ICU, with Covid and we couldn’t even visit him. I was worried, but ­thankfully he pulled through.“At first, I planned to keep the tree up until he was discharged and could visit, but then we went into lockdown so he wasn’t allowed to come here. “I decided to keep the tree to cheer us all up in January. But there always seemed to be another reason to redecorate it. A year on, here we are.” Will the tree remain up in   Vicki replies: “I haven’t decided yet. “My twin sons turn  next year and want a ‘birthday tree’ so I’ll do that. I won’t be surprisedI find a few more reasons to keep it up…” Here, Vicki takes us through her tree for all seasons… January  I put away the decorations, just keeping the lights on, and redecorated the tree with white and silver tinsel and stars which I borrowed from my mum.January felt so bleak and frightening, the country in lockdown and people dying of Covid, and I wanted our tree to be a light in the darkness.I found it soothing sitting by it, and it reminded me happier times would come again.February  I got the inspiration for this tree from Pinterest, where I saw lots of images of Valentine’s trees, which have become a new interior decor trend in recent years.I bought the decorations from a local pound shop, including heart lights and cardboard hearts, and it cost me less than a tenner. Although we’re not usually very romantic for Valentine’s, this year I wanted to spread some love in my home.March  Mother’s Day fell in March this year and to celebrate all the amazing mums out there who were working, home-schooling and caring for others during lockdown, as well as my own mum Mandy, , I created this special tree.The flowers in it are all articial and taken from a vase I had in the house. I spent a few pounds on the floral bunting and “Mum” balloon. Hung on the tree were little photos of my two grandmothers who have passed away.April  This was my second tree in the month of April, to mark my daughter Niamh’s th birthday.She couldn’t have a party because of Covid restrictions, but I still wanted to make the day special for her, so I created a “birthday tree”. She had no idea, I sent her away to my sister’s house for the night, so I could decorate it as a surprise and her face when she walked in the door was priceless. She absolutely loved it. Now all the kids want one for their birthdays.May  Of all the trees, this one is the most personal to me. In , I lost twin daughters called Daisy and Chloe  weeks into my pregnancy.I went on to have my twin sons Lennon and Dexter, now , but I’ve never forgotten my daughters and, after deciding to do a “spring” tree, I used a daisy theme to honour them. I used yellow streamers and glued paper daisies to them, which was time consuming, but it’s one of my favourite trees of the year. June  My husband and one of my sons are football mad, and the country was gripped by Euros fever, so I decided to do an England tree, to get behind the team.This one was very simple and inexpensive, with just aof flags and a few football helium balloons at the top. But it was fab having it there in the living room as we cheered on the England team all the way to the final.July, August and September I felt so happy this summer – the weather was great, and le felt a lot more normal again.I celebrated with a summer-themed tree, decorated with cardboard watermelon slices, flamingos, butterflies and huge tissue paper flowers, as well as rainbows as a reminder of all the key workers who worked so hard. The carers for my elderly neighbours love my trees and often park their car outside my house just to have a look and feel cheered up.October  It was time to get spooky in October and make a Halloween tree, something I knew the children in the local area would especially love.I made the tree look dark by draping black webbing over it and picked up most of the decorations for pennies in a local charity shop, plus stuff I had in the house from previous Halloweens. We had lots of trick-or-treaters call to the door, who were very impressed with it.November  Remembrance Sunday is an important day for us. My husband served in the Navy and both my brothers served in the Army.My mother and father-in-law died in September within  days of one another. They always went to the local march, and my mother-in-law used to carry the flag. I made all the poppies from tissue paper. It was very therapeutic, thinking about veterans and their sacrice.December  Christmas is just around the corner and my tree is back to its festive best, with a new Santa hat for the top and lots of lights and tinsel… all of which I had in the loft.I made the flowers and the holly berries myself. I’ve got really crafty in the past year. People have assumed I’ve spent a fortune, but I’ve actually only spent around £ since this time last year. After last Christmas, I can’t wait for the festive season to begin. It’s going to be so special to bring my family together for food, games and fun, and we can all enjoy my tree which has really helped me and my family through a hard year.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Christmas trees" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news mum-whose-house-absolutely-covered-"Hull: Shock footage shows damp and mould in houseByIvan Morris PoxtonShiler Mahmoudi:,  Dec | commentsA mum living in a house aposabsolutely coveredapos in mould and damp fears for the health of her two young children. The concerned mum-of-two, Erin, whose name has been changed to protect her identity, lives with her five-year-old son and baby daughter in Hull.Their family house has been devoured in damp and mould, and she has been raising the issues with her landlord for almost two years, Hull Live reports.In January , she first notied Preston Road Womenaposs Centre, operating as Winner Trading Ltd, of the signicant issue in her home, but not date the matter remains unsolved. Erin has even had a number of visits from Hull City Councilaposs environmental health team who said thatthe repairs are not made, action may be taken by the council.  Speaking to Hull Live on her behalf, Erinaposs partner, Chris, whose name has also been changed, said: The house is absolutely covered in damp and mould, thataposs the worst thing about it. Itaposs in the bathroom, both bedrooms and the living room. Every single wall in the front, living room has it. Itaposs damaged furniture and even damaged a TV unit. My partner messages quite often and gets blanked.  According to Chris, the landlord has made no attempt to repair the problem, and two years, the family are frustrated and concerned. He said: What they told us to do was to wipe it down. But we have done that once and it just comes straight back. Erin hopes to move into a council property in order to escape the nightmare living conditions and to live with Chris, but so far, she has not had much luck in securing a property. The couple are anxious that being trapped in the property may have long-term health impacts on the two young children. Iaposve also been in contact with environmental health from Hull City Council, Chris added. Theyaposve visited twice already and are set to visit again this month. Chris said that environmental health last visited in November and had made recommendations to the landlords, Winner Trading Ltd, to take action on the issues with the property.  Preston Road Womenaposs Centre said: In line with the schedule of works issued by the local authority environmental health office, Winner Trading investigated the cause of the damp. Some remedial works have already been done at the property, we have identied there are further works required which will be implemented.A Hull City Council spokeswoman confirmed that members of environmental health had visited the property and said: The council inspected the property in July and identied a schedule of work required by the landlord, Winner Trading Ltd, to improvethe accommodation.A further visit recently showed that improvements were underway but a number of the scheduled items identied in the previous visit remained unaddressed, therefore a further visit has been arranged for later this month. If the work hasn’t been completed, the council will take appropriate formal enforcement action under the Housing Act . story: New place named UKs Covid capital as  areas see a rise - view the listOf  local authority areas in the UK,  saw a rise in cases, while the number of people testing positive fell in  places, with Torridge in Devon now the worst hotspotNew hotspots are emerging, with the south of England appearing to be worst affected Image: SIPA USA PA ImagesByIan JonesDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments More than  areas in the UK have seen a week-on-week rise in Covid cases - with Torridge in Devon now the worst hotspot, the latest data shows.Figures reveal that the district in the South West has the highest infection rate, followed by Gwynedd in Wales and Mid Sussex. Southern England, Wales and Northern Ireland are recording the highest rate of infections. But there is some encouraging news, with more than half of local authority areas recording a fall in new infections. Of  local authority areas in the UK,  saw a rise in cases, while the number of people testing positive fell in  places. Ashford in Kent and Hart in Hampshire recorded the largest jump in new cases, Public Health England data shows.Scroll down to see what Covid rates are in your area according to latest figures Torridge in Devon continues to have the highest rate in the UK, with  new cases in the seven days to November  - the equivalent of ,. per , people. This is up slightly from ,. in the seven days to November . Gwynedd in Wales has the second highest rate, down slightly from . to ., with , new cases. Mid Sussex has the third highest rate, down from . to ., with , new cases. Antrim  Newtownabbey has the highest rate in Northern Irelandand Falkirk has the highest rate in Scotland . The five UK areas with the biggest week-on-week rises are:AshfordHartGedlingBrentwoodMaldon  In the past week , people have tested positive for the virus, latest Department of Health figures show. This is a slight rise of . per cent compared to the previous week. Boris Johnson has said people do not need to cancel their festive plans in light of the Omicron iant of coronavirus.The Prime Minister, who received his booster dose of the Covid vaccine yesterday, urged the public to continue as they are within the new measures introduced to stop the spread of the virus. Mr Johnson, speaking to broadcasters at St Thomasapos Hospital in London, said: I want to repeat the guidance is there and Iaposm very, very keen that people understand this, we donapost want people to feel that they need to start cancelling things, to start... you talk about kids in nativity plays and that kind of thing. I donapost think thereaposs any need to stop that at all. I think weaposre taking a balanced and proportionate approach to the risk, but I want and I believe that Christmas this year will be considerably better than Christmas last year. title: primary school pupil confirmed omicron
story: Primary school pupil confirmed to have Omicron as booster jabs spark hopeOmicron has already brought with it new restrictions, and a primary school pupil in Scotland has been confirmed to be the latest to have contracted the iantThe latest confirmed case was detected at Rosebank Primary School in Nairn, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Scotland to  Image: Google mapsByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A primary school pupil has tested positive for the Omicron Covid iant, it has been confirmed. The news comes as a new study boosted hopes vaccines offer a good level of protection against the mutated virus.The latest confirmed case was detected at Rosebank Primary School in Nairn, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Scotland to . A further  cases have also been confirmed in England, with an update on numbers expected to come later today. The UK government has already taken steps to combat the spread of the latest strain, with compulsory masks being re-introduced in shops and on public transport, and PCR tests for anyone arriving into the UK.  Worrying graphics have shown just how mutated the newly-emerged Omicron iant is, with illustrations released by the Genomics UK Consortiumshow that it has a worrying  mutations on its spike protein.By comparison Delta - which tore through the population last winter and has since become the worldaposs dominant strain - has seven. Experts have said Omicron, which was first identied by scientists in South Africa, is the most mutated Covid iant they have yet encountered. Yesterday a spokesman for the UK Health Security Agency told The Mirror that targeted testing is being carried out for the iant. This means that not every positive PCR test is screened for the new strain. In good news, experts behind a major new study have suggested booster vaccines offer good protection against the Omicron iant.  A team looking at the effects of third doses said the bodyaposs T cell immune response after a booster shot is such that it may provide protection from hospital admission and death. The study also says mRNA jabs, including Pfizer and Moderna, lead to the most signicant rise in immunity levels.Professor Saul Faust, trial lead and director of the NIHR Clinical Research Facility at University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust, said: All of the vaccines in our study do show a statistically signicant boost. RNAvery high, but very effective boosts from Novavax, Janssen and AstraZeneca as well. He said the CovBoost study had shown that six dferent vaccines are safe and effective as booster doses for people who have already had two doses of AstraZeneca or Pfizer BioNTech. The six vaccines tested as a third dose were AstraZeneca, Pfizer BioNTech, Moderna, Novavax, Janssenand CureVac . He added that the vaccines worked well against existing iants, although Omicron was not tested in the study. But experts think that T cell immunity - which was studied alongside antibodies in the research - could also play a signicant role in fending off the new iant. T cells play a key role and work alongside antibodies in the immune system to target viruses. Prof Faust said: Even though we donapost properly understand its relation to long-term immunity, the T cell data is showing us that it does seem to be broader against all the iant strains. Which gives us hope that a iant strain of the virus might be able to be handled, certainly for hospitalisation and deathnot prevention of infection, by the current vaccines. news uk-news prince-georges-favourite-dinner-revealed-"Bear Grylls recalls the moment Prince George ate his first antByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | comments Most kids have that one thing they love to sit down to for dinner after a long day at school - including Prince George. His favourite dish was once revealed by his proud dad Prince William to TV chef Aldo Zilli, and itaposs an Italian classic.So what does the young prince love so much  Spaghetti carbonara, apparently!Aldo previously told FEMAIL : apos[Williamaposs] amazing - Iaposm waiting for the call because apparently his little boyaposs favourite is spaghetti carbonara, so Iaposm waiting for the call to go and cook it for him.If George has my carbonara, he will never have another one, so I need to go and make it, letaposs get the ball rolling, send me to the palace to cook!  Itaposs not the first time that a favourite food of the Cambridge children has been revealed.The Duchess of Cambridge once told of Princess Charlotteaposs favourite snack - and itaposs very unusual - olives.Kate revealed her daughteraposs favourite food on a visit to Lavender Primary School in north London in . Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. During the visit to the school, she also revealed that she was teaching George as well as Charlotte to cook. She said that her children love to “make salads and stuff” as well as their signature dish, cheesy pasta.Meanwhile, when it comes to Prince Louis, his favourite food is beetroot. When filming with Mary Berry for a TV Christmas special in , Kate ulged: Weaposve got carrots, beans, beetroot – a massive favourite – Louis absolutely loves beetroot. However, there is one royal who never tells anybody what her favourite food is, and thataposs the Queen. And thereaposs a rather good reason why what she likes best is kept so secret.  A royal insider has explained how the Queen doesnapost ulge her favourite food before travelling so that she isnapost served the same thing everywhere she goes. As reported by The Express, Gordon Rayner, former royal correspondent for Thewho has covered more than  royal tours, said heaposd discovered this fact from a royal staff member.He said: As one of her staff told me, ‘If she said she had a favourite meal she would never get served anything .’ Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Aldo ZilliPrince GeorgePrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pubs closing record rate 40
story: Pubs closing at record rate of  a week during pandemic as lockdowns take tollWhen restrictions first hit home in March last year, there were , pubs and bars across Britain - with that figure dwindling to just , by SeptemberPubs are closing at a record rate of  a week during the pandemic as lockdowns take their toll Image: Getty ImagesByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsPubs closed at a record rate of  a week during the pandemic as lockdowns took their toll.When restrictions first hit home in March last year, there were , pubs and bars across Britain. By September this year, that had dwindled to just ,. Among those lost were The White Horse in Churton, Cheshire, and The Butlers Arms in Pleasington, Lancs, which had been run by top chef, Michael Hales.It is thought most of the struggling pubs were run by independent landlords who were less able to withstand the financial impact of the lockdowns than pub companies, despite help from taxpayer-backed loans and grants. Last week, Wetherspoons also called time on the Running Horses in St Helens, Merseyside – one of the town’s biggest nightle venues. Changing drinking habits had already caused pub numbers to fall from around , in . But , closures took place in the  months of the pandemic. Graeme Smith, of AlixPartners, which revealed the figures, said: “Clearly the pandemic will have accelerated closure numbers for ­businesses that may have already been struggling to remain viable.” Rick Robinson, landlord of the Willoughby Arms in Kingston upon Thames, Surrey, said trade in the past four months was  per cent to  per cent down on the same time in . He said: “I think the public are still generally very nervous.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Graeme SmithWhite Horse BerhadPubs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: seven year old girl given
story: Seven-year-old girl was given three months to live after repeatedly rubbing her legsNicola Catons daughter Isla has been fighting cancer since she was two. Her mum is determined that this Christmas will not be her little girls lastIslas mum is fighting for her daughter Image: MyLondon WSByAyokunle Oluwalana:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A mum whose young daughter was given a devastating cancer diagnosis is in a race against time to save her le. Nicola Catonaposs daughter Isla is just seven years old and has been fighting the disease since she was two. Her family, from Stratford, East London, have been searching all over trying to find the right treatment and clinical trial which would help her, after a doctor gave her just three months to live. For mum Nicola, this has been five years of seeing her daughter battle the aggressive cancer and she is determined that this will not be her last Christmas.Before she was unwell, we used to call her aposbam bamapos. She was full of energy, Nicola told My London.She was a big, bouncy baby. Then, she was unwell for three months before she even got a diagnosis. Suddenly when Isla was just two, everything changed.  Nicola noticed that she was losing weight, had high temperatures and was always in pain and rubbing her legs. She took Isla to the hospital a number of times and said that AE said I was being over-sensitive about everything. Nicole knew something was wrong and insisted on Isla being checked out and eventually went to a private doctor. She said: When he examined her and saw how much weight she lost, he turned to me and said aposI think this is something seriousapos. They did an ultrasound. He told us it was cancer. I fainted. We never dreamed this would happen to our big, healthy baby.  Isla had been diagnosed with Neuroblastoma, a rare type of cancer that mostly affects babies or young children, and started treatment at Great Ormond Street Hospital. It was there that Nicola met families with children going through a similar situation to Isla. When we first started fundraising, the other families told us that Neuroblastoma is extremely hard to cureyou relapse, she said. There is only a  per cent chance of survival at the beginning. As treatment began on Isla, the plan was to get her into remission and take her to America for a clinical trial. Nicola said: If we could get Isla into remission, there was a vaccine in America that would hopefully prevent the cancer relapsing. Sadly, Isla relapsed before she finished her frontline treatment, as doctors found a brain tumour, which was then removed. As the family tried to fundraise for another treatment in the US, Isla relapsed again. There were now several spots on her bones. She said: In July , our consultant basically looked at us and said. aposTake her home. Sheaposs got three months to liveapos. This news was heartbreaking for the family but Nicola could never give up hope for her little girl. She reached out to doctors worldwide about Neuroblastoma and spoke to parents going through the same turmoil. She said: The consultant called us and said Isla only has a two per cent chance of survival now.  I said, aposwhy canapost Isla be dferent aposItaposs this sheer determination that caused the family to fundraise to give Isla a better chance at le and hopefully find a cure.The family spent two years in Barcelona and the family were accessing trial after trial to try and get Isla back into remission. Things seemed to look up for her when she went into remission but in February , she relapsed again. Nicola said: In Spain, we spent around £, on medical bills. It was really hard, there were constant bills, paying for our house in the UK. Our only focus was on getting Isla back into remission. At the start of the pandemic in March , the family left Spain and moved back to London. This was a devastating blow to the family as they couldnapost go out and fundraise or access any treatment. We werenapost able to access any treatments, Nicola explained. We made a decision that after July that we wouldnapost be able to go back to Spain.Thankfully we found something on the NHS but unfortunately it didnapost work. Then on Christmas Eve, they told us itaposs not working.Since then itaposs just been chemotherapy to chemotherapy. Trying to hold the cancer at bay. Nicola feels sad for Isla. She doesnapost know any dferent and has missed out on a number of things just trying to live. Nicola said: She was miserable in Spain. She missed her sister. For the last five years, Iaposve focused on saving her le. We had to make a decision on whether we gave her a great le or tried to save it. At the beginning of , I vowed to give her the best le possible. Weaposd really like to make a lot of memories and let her enjoy everything. The plan for December is to have Father Christmas visit their home and spend quality time with the rest of the family. In the New Year, they want to be able to take her to CBeebies. Nicola added: The thing you miss most in the world is normality. Just being around family and having her home. A big part of Islaaposs battle is also to raise awareness for Neuroblastoma. Weaposre a working-class family and the people who have helped are just normal people, Nicola added. Itaposs really amazing. But you shouldnapost have to raise huge amounts of money to save your childaposs le.You can donate to crowdfunding here. title: sister tears defendants phone call
story: Sister in tears at defendants phone call admitting to killing Sir Richard SuttonAccused Thomas Schreiber called his sister Louisa Schreiber, , from prison and apologised for the attack which killed multi-millionaire landowner and hotelier Sir Richard Sutton, a court heardLouisa Schreiber arrived at Winchester Crown Court to hear back the phone call her brother Thomas had made to her Image: Ewan Galvin Solent NewsByBen MitchellSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec The sister of Thomas Schreiber sobbed in court as a recording was played of a telephone call he made to her from prison, in which he apologised for the attack which killed Sir Richard Sutton and paralysed their mother. The -year-old defendant is on trial at Winchester Crown Court accused of the murder of the millionaire hotelier and attempted murder of his mother, Anne Schreiber. The court was told that Schreiber called his sister, Louisa Schreiber, , while on remand at HMP Winchester awaiting trial. During the call, Schreiber told his sister: I am so sorry, absolute complete madness, I am waking up every day hoping to wake up from this nightmare. I had a complete loss of control, itaposs complete madness, it doesnapost make any sense and I am so sorry, I didnapost mean for any of this to happen, I didnapost want to hurt anyone and I have done the opposite. He added: I completely flipped, that wasnapost me that day, it wasnapost Tom Schreiber, it was someone , it was demons. Iaposm so sorry I did that to mum and Richard, itaposs so regrettable, everything is so regrettable, all I want to do is turn back the clock to April , it doesnapost seem real, I didnapost mean it, I just want to give mum a hug. The defendant also asked his sister in the call about his motheraposs condition, and she explained his kne attack had partially severed her spinal cord in her neck, leaving her paralysed and unable to breathe without a ventilator. Ms Schreiber suffered up to  separate injuries, including wounds to the back of her head, arm and chest, as well as to her neck, shoulder and back, in the attack. Ms Schreiber sobbed while the recording was played and the judge, Mr Justice Garnham, allowed her to compose herself before answering questions. The defendant, wearing a suit and tie, held his head down throughout the recording. Sir Richardaposs daughter, Caroline Sutton, who broke down in tears as she gave evidence behind a screen, said that her father had given each of the Schreiber siblings £, as deposits to buy a house, along with the monthly £, allowance. She said: My father was constantly talking about wanting him out of the house and he wouldnapost go. He constantly talked about Tom, about how Tom was rude and disrespectful and wouldnapost help him. I suggested he got him somewhere to live and he said Tom wouldnapost go. Her husband, Steven Woodward, told the court: Richard struggled with the fact that Tom was lazy, of Tom not showing any respect to Richard and his mother and his sisters. It had become a bit of a joke that Sir Richard would become obsessed because it had become so bad for him, he was a prisoner in his own home. Describing the defendant, he added: This is a person who felt the world owed him a living, he is sarcastic, he thought he was better than everyone . Schreiber denies the murder of his stepfather and denies attempted murder of his mother, and the trial continues.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Court caseCrown courtMurder trial" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: six cases omicron covid variant
story: Six cases of Omicron Covid iant linked to Steps concert at Glasgow’s HydroScotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said that an increase in Omicron cases are linked to the Steps concert at Glasgows Hydro on November , along with other sourcesA Steps concert at Glasgows Hydro on November  has been linked to the  new Omicron cases Image: Getty ImagesByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsSix cases of the new Omicron Covid iant have been linked to a Steps concert in Glasgow. The concert took place on November  at the SSE Hydro, but as of yet, no cases have been linked to the concert that happened the following day. Scottish officials confirmed that there had been  new cases of the iant recorded in the past  hours, taking the overall number to . It was confirmed by Nicola Sturgeon, Scotlandaposs First Minister, that the Steps concert, as well as some other sources, are linked to the rise in Omicron cases. Leaders have said that while the risk to those who were at the show is low, they were working to get in touch with anyone who may have come into contact with the strain of the virus.  No one from the concert needs to isolate unless they are contacted to do so. Nicola Sturgeon, Scotlandaposs First Minister said: “The number of Omicron cases now being reported in Scotland is rising, and cases are no longer all linked to a single event, but to several dferent sources including a Steps concert at the Hydro on November . “This confirms our view that there is now community transmission of this iant within Scotland. Given the nature of transmission we would expect to see cases rise – perhaps signicantly – in the days ahead.  “However, health protection teams are continuing work through contact tracing, isolation and testing to slow the spread as far as possible while we learn more about the new iant’s impact. Ministers are also keeping the situation under daily review.” Cases of the new iant have been recorded in Highland, Grampian and Forth Valley health boards for the first time, at three, one and five respectively. Previously, nine cases of Omicron were linked to single private event a few weeks ago on November .  NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde is now home to  cases, while NHS Lanarkshire has nine.The latest figures state that over the last  hours, Scotland has had  recorded coronavirus-related deaths along with . This brings Scotlandaposs total deaths to  with  people in intensive care since Wednesday night. So far, ,, people have received their first COVID vaccine, ,, have had their second, and ,, have been given a third dose or booster. title: teenage coronation street fans day
story: Exclusive: Brave teen Corrie fans day of joy after being granted final wish to visit setDad Simon Cross recalled the touching visit to the Corrie set he made with his then -year-old daughter Hannah who had been diagnosed with cancerHannah Cross dream came true as she visited the set of Corrie Image: CollectByClaire OBoyleAssistant Features Editor Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Marking his th birthday with a charity skye, Simon Cross felt on top of the world. He had raised £, for Make-A-Wish UK and liked their work so much he began volunteering for them.Four years later, the dad of two was on the set of Coronation Street with his young daughter Hannah as she was granted a wish by the charity after being diagnosed with cancer.“After seeing the whole process from the inside and helping families through the most heartbreaking moments of their lives, suddenly the roles were reversed,” says Simon. “I found myself on the other side, turning to Make-A-Wish for something that could bring comfort and joy to my own sick child. “When we found out how ill Hannah was, our world fell apart.” He was an environmental health officer with the RAF in  when -year-old Hannah was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive soft tissue cancer. It was already stage four.  Simon, , says: “By this point I’d volunteered with Make-A-Wish for three years and I’d always been in awe of how families I met dealt with what they were facing. I’d felt huge empathy for them, but I never pictured myself going through it.” Hannah had a six-month course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Simon says: “She lost all her hair and parts of that time felt horric. “But Hannah was brilliant. However horrible it got, she kept on smiling. She was inspirational.” Afterwards, things seemed hopeful. She continued with maintenance chemo and, as her strength built up and her hair started to grow back, Simon and we Donna, , had more reason to be positive. They then decided to reach out to Make-A-Wish UK, this year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal charity. Simon, of Sleaford, Lincs, says: “I’d seen how having a wish granted could give families a real lt.” Hannah, then , asked the charity to arrange a Corrie visit for her and her family. Simon says the treat in November  was “wonderful”. He adds: “Make-A-Wish arranged a trip to Manchester over a couple of days. We were picked up in a limo from our hotel and taken to Granada Studios. “Hannah loved it. I remember we were greeted by Kate Ford, who plays Tracy Barlow, and she was lovely to us all. “Hannah loved walking around the set and seeing the cast. She got lots of autographs and loved meeting David Neilson, who plays Roy Cropper.”  Hannah and her older brother Callum even had a stint as extras. Simon says: “She could feel normal for a day. She could forget about hospitals and scans and chemo and have a fun day with her family where none of that mattered.” Then, just after Christmas in , Hannah noticed a lump in her neck and was taken back to hospital. It was on the day her appearance on Corrie was broadcast in January  that doctors gave the family the news that she had relapsed. “Still we hoped for a miracle,” says Simon, who will share her story at tonight’s Make-A-Wish Ball in London. She had more chemo but by September doctors said there was nothing more they could do. “We took her home from hospital and had her there for six days before we lost her on September , ,” Simon says. He adds his involvement with the charity gave him – as well as his we and son Callum, now  – a reason to stay positive.  Simon says: “Everyone is dferent in how they grieve, but for me carrying on with Make-A-Wish helped.” The year after Hannah’s death, Simon set about an amazing challenge in her honour. “She was  when we lost her,” he says. “So I decided to do  half marathons. I raised money for a number of charities, including Make-A-Wish. “I had a sign with me with a picture of Hannah. Every time I was struggling I remembered all she had been through and it helped me keep going.” He still volunteers with the charity and says of the granted wish: “We’ll never forget the joy it brought her.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON David NeilsonKate FordCoronation StreetHospitalsSoap operasCancerMirror Christmas appeal" data-immediate"data-immediate"Dont miss out on the biggest soaps gossip! news uk-news three-signs-omicron-covid-look-"Omicron Covid iant: Symptoms to look out forByTom Ambrose:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsHealth chiefs believe the Omicron Covid iant causes mild illness for most people but there are early signs it may cause dferent symptoms than earlier strains. Scientists are racing to work outthe new iant, first discovered in southern Africa, spreads faster, circumvents vaccines or causes worse side affects.Experts say people are presenting cold-like symptoms since receiving the vaccine and according to the ZOE Covid symptom study app, people who test positive most commonly report a headache, runny nose, sore throat and sneezing. Dr Angelique Coetzee, chair of the South African Medical Association, said the main symptoms of Cmicron to look out for are:Fatigue Body aches Headache She described one “very interesting case” of a six-year-old girl who had “a temperature and a very high pulse rate, The Sun reports. A World Health Organizationofficial has told the Reuters news agency that most people are not getting seriously ill, although it could still be the case.  Dr Maria Van Kerkhove, a top WHO adviser, said: “In terms of the severity profile, we have seen reports of cases with Omicron that go from mild disease all the way to severe disease. “There is some indication that some of the patients are presenting with mild disease, but again it is early days. We do have a surveillance bias right now in terms of the cases that are being detected.  “There is also a suggestion of increased hospitalisations across South Africa, but that could be the sheer fact that we have more cases. “If you have more cases you will have more hospitalisations.” Meanwhile, a health director in Botswana said  out of  people infected had no symptoms, while the other three had “very, very mild” illness. It comes as nine more cases of the Omicron iant were discovered in England taking the total across the country to .Cases have now been identied in the East Midlands, East of England, London, South East and North West. A further case has been identied in Scotland, bringing the total to . title: uks hottest curry tried nations
story: UKs hottest curry: We tried nations spiciest dishes including crocodile meat infernoFrom Yorkshire to London, we scoured Britain for the most fearsome, fiery curries money can buy – and found some truly nightmarish dishesChefs cooking the Crocodile Inferno have to wear a gas mask for their own protection Image: Sam BagnallByGreg FordDan HallFeatures WriterLaura Connor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Curry is the nation’s favourite dish, so it’s only proper that we treat it with some reverence.Earlier this week, the great and good from the curry world donned black tie for a glitzy London event referred to as the Curry Oscars.The British Curry Awards, which have been attended by Love Islanders and Prime Ministers alike, recognise the best restaurants serving spicy food across the country. Last year there were special gongs given out for the best takeaways and family teams operating during the pandemic. But this year, we want to know the answer to a burning question overlooked by the Curry Oscars: where can we find the hottest curry in the UK   Many restaurants have made the audacious claim over the years, from eateries in Edinburgh right down to luxury establishments in London. The hottest type of curry generally available across Britain is the fearsome Phaal, a dish even hotter than vindaloo. But some sadistic chefs have made it their mission to go even further, cooking up something so hot that just eating it - let alone enjoying it - is a challenge. We set out to try some of the spiciest curries around the country to see which was the hottest – so you don’t have to.Crocodile Inferno, The Dilshad, Cannock, Staffordshire By Dan Hall What happened to me at The Dilshad in Cannock, Staff., was profound and humbling.The restaurant is home to the notorious Crocodile Inferno - a curry so diabolically hot that diners have to sign a disclaimer acknowledging what theyaposre letting themselves in for before buying it. As the name suggests, the dish is made with crocodile meat because, as restaurant ownerTony Uddin explains, it absorbs more of the spice.  There are over  chillies included in the £ dish, including some of the most formidable on the planet. Tony says: “Some of the hottest are the Trinidad scorpion - which is very competitive. “And we also use fresh Naga which is also just ridiculously hot.” You have to give the restaurant two daysapos noticeyou want a Crocodile Inferno because it takes that long to assemble the full bestiary of ingredients.  Aside from the disclaimer, there are a couple of other chilling insights into what Iaposm about to eat before the curry even arrives at the table.One is that Tony insists I sit in an area away from other diners in case the fumes from my dish are too strong for customers sitting at another table .And the other is that the chef preparing my meal wears a gas mask for his own protection while handling the weapons-grade spice. The portents of doom continue when the waiter brings the curry to my table.  Before he even takes the lid off the dish, the spice is so pungent that my eyes start to water. But even with all of these red flags, nothing could prepare me for whataposs about to happen when I take my first taste. As soon as the sauce touches my lips, the burning sensation is instantaneous and incredible, roughly akin to what I imagine it would be like to be flamethrowered in the face. When the heat reaches my throat, I feel like Iaposm swallowing a chainsaw, and I start to hyperventilate as Iaposm consumed with agony.  For some sick reason I decide to persevere with the ordeal, hoping I might adjust to the Saturn V rocket launching on my tongue. But I donapost - it just keeps getting worse the more mouthfuls I have, with the searing pain intensying until my vision blurs and my hands start to tingle. Iaposm knocking back beer to try and take the temperature down, but it doesnapost help - I wouldaposve happily necked a pint of liquid nitrogen had there been one to hand. After about  minutes of heaving in a truly undignied manner and with the harrowing prospect of tomorrow morning in mind, I decide to throw in the towel. Our soap newsletter will be delivered to your inbox with the latest upcoming storylines, big s and surprise exits. The Mirror TV team are on hand to ensure youaposre up to date on the dozens of weekly soap spoilers, glossy nostalgia and big TV moments. Donapost miss a moment from soap land by signing up to our email here. For those who really hate their own nervous system, Tony tells me heaposs currently working on an even spicier version of the Inferno to be launched next year which will use shark meat. To anyone interested, I promise you the crocodile is deadly enough.Prawn Rogan Josh, MyLahore, Bradford, West Yorkshire By Laura Connor I head to UK curry capital Bradford to sample one of their hottest curries at one of the city’s flagship Indian restaurants, MyLahore.I don’t mind reasonably spicy food and normally enjoy a tomato-based Rogan Josh as long as I can specy it comes with medium heat. But I can barely get through a mouthful of their hottest prawn version, even when it’s absorbed by mounds of pilau rice and washed down with an entire jug of lemon water.  At least I’ve definitely drank today’s daily recommended eight glasses of water in just one sitting. This recipe is made with seven bullet chillies - which rack up ,-, heat units on the Scoville scale , used to measure chilli spice levels - mixed with classic Madras spices, including eye-watering amounts of cayenne pepper and mustard powder. I take a deep breath before trying the scarlet-red curry, with visible bright green chillies menacingly winking at me from the sauce. My waiter kindly brings over some yogurt and mint dip to help cool my mouth down - before askingI would like to try their newest menu addition: spicy chicken wings.  I try one and my mouth feels like an angry volcano so I politely ask for some Tupperware to take them home in. Hopefully my mouth will have cooled down by lunchtime tomorrow…City Spice Challenge, City Spice, Brick Lane, London By Dan HallThereaposs no single street in Britain more synonymous with curries than Londonaposs Brick Lane. The legendary road was once home to  curry houses in the mid-s, with over a dozen still going today.One of the best of them is City Spice, which has been referred to as the “King of Brick Lane” thanks to its endless accolades - which have included the Masterchef curry award  for best restaurant in London. As well as delicious delicacies, the Indian eatery is home to the City Spice Challenge. Manager Reez Haque, , says the restaurant wanted to cook up a punishingly hot dish that could put even the most ardent spice lovers through their paces. The £. meal is a bhuna from hell, souped-up with some of the hottest chillies known to science. One is the dreaded Carolina Reaper, the Guinness World Record holder for hottest chilli which clocks in at a shuddersome . million SHU.  For context, the pepper spray police use to incapacitate people is about  million SHU. Reez says: “The reason we started the challenge was to do something for the local community. “The idea was thata diner could finish it off, whatever they pay for the dish would go to charity. “Instead of putting the chillies directly into the dish, we blend them and get the juice out.  “The benefit of doing that is that it doesn’t kill the flavour of the other ingredients.” After the first mouthful, I feel pretty cocky that Iaposll be able to get through the City Spice Challenge without breaking a sweat. But the hubris doesn’t last long. As with a thermonuclear blast in the distance, the heat doesnapost hit you right away - you just get a flash of it on the first bite foretelling the fire to come.  The heat builds and builds until my mouth is a furnace, but Iaposm just about able to keep my cool. And perversely, by the time I finish, I actually quite enjoyed it. Butyouaposre going out for dinner, there must be something seriously wrong with youthis is the level of heat that you actually want - evenit is for a good cause!Circle of Fire, The Crooked Skewer, Hull, East Yorkshire By Greg FordWe were warned. Crooked Skewer owner Aminul Choudhury sits calmly by the table as he outlines the reduction process he has perfected to produce what he believes is one of the hottest curries in the county. In truth ‘The Circle of Fire’ is a beast born from a touch of madness kg of chillies including Ghost Pepper, Scorpion Pepper and Carolina Reaper dried and made into a paste.  The curry is then reduced over several days until it barely fills a bowl, with nothing added except water, because Aminul says he doesn’t want to risk losing heat. The grill house beef is seared and thinly sliced before being glazed in a nine million SHU sauce named ‘Hell Unleashed’. Aminul estimates the heat of the dish at five million SHU, and after tasting it I’m not in a mood to disagree with him.  The spice is present on the first bite, searing on the second and unbearable by the third. Flashes of flavour are replaced with a pure and painful heat, numb lips and an insatiable appetite for mango lassi. Fellow diners bravely accepting the tempting offer of a freebie instantly regret their choice.  One woman runs for the bathroom while a man showing off on a date makes a fool of himself by crying. Genuinely the hottest dish to pass my lips and I hope for my body’s sake it stays that way. title: woman 86 finally reunited wedding
story: Woman, , is finally reunited with wedding ring lost  years ago in the sPeggy MacSween, who lost the ring in the late s, thought she would never see it again until a fellow islander tracked it down with his metal detectorPeggy MacSween believed she would never see the ring againByTom Ambrose:,  Dec | commentsA woman has expressed her shock after being reunited with a wedding ring she lost while gathering potatoes in Scotlandaposs Western Isles five decades ago. Peggy MacSween, who lost the ring in the late s, thought she would never see it again after the band slipped from her finger on Benbecula. However, fellow islander Donald MacPhee learned of the mystery of the missing ring and offered to find it with his trusty metal detector. Mr MacPhee, who runs Benbeculaaposs Nunton House Hostel, discovered it after searching an area where the potato patch was for three long days, digging  holes in the process. Before the miraculous finding, he also unearthed rubbish including old metal, drinks cans and ring pulls before finding the once cherished wedding ring, reports BBC News.Mrs MacSween, , said: He just came to the door and said: aposI have something to show youapos. It was the ring. I couldnapost believe it, but there it was. I thought I would never see it again. The ring, from her wedding in July , was originally when she was gathering potatoes on Liniclate Machair, an area of sandy coastal meadow in the late s.  She added: I was shaking the sand out of my gloves and the ring disappeared. I didnapost know until I got home. I went out once or twice to look for it, but there was no way of finding it. Her husband John died a few years ago but had bought her a replacement while the couple were on holiday. Until then, she had been wearing her motheraposs wedding ring. title: woman spotted riding through mcdonalds
story: Woman spotted riding through McDonalds drive-through on a horseSimon White from Caerphilly, Wales had stopped by his local McDonalds for a quick bite to eat, but was amused to see a woman queue up and order her food, all while perching on a white horseThe horsed seemed to be unbothered as they queued up and paid for her meal Image: Deadline NewsByRyan NixonShiler Mahmoudi:,  Dec | comments A woman was spotting riding through a McDonaldaposs drive through and ordering a meal - on a horse.Dad-of-three Simon White saw the hilarious event unfold while stopping to eat at his local McDonaldaposs in Caerphilly, Wales on Thursday.The woman stood in the queue, paid at the first window and then collected her meal at the second while Simon,  took some photos of the bizarre incident.His pictures show the woman in a mustard puffer jacket and riding boots sitting on a white horse and joining the line as though nothing is out of the ordinary.She holds her purse in her hand, ready to pay for her snack, and then pays for her food while perched on her horse. The horse seems to not be phased and waits for her to finish patiently, and the two ride off after the staff members give her her meal. Speaking today, Simon a vehicle parts constructor, said: I was on my way home from collecting my little one from school when we stopped by for something to eat.We were sitting there waiting for our food when she came round the corner.I couldnapost believe it - the horse was very well-behaved though and she got served no problem, before riding off. A few of the kids who were sitting inside came out to take pictures and cheer her as they thought it was great. He added: She was served and rode off. Then I passed her on the road where she was eating the burger.My son loved it, it really made his day - he was laughing so much.I thought it was really funny as well - itaposs something you just canapost imagine seeing unless you live in the Welsh valleys. Simon shared the images to social media with the caption aposWell Iaposve seen it all now...only in the Valleys,apos and it has since received a lot of attention by amused internet users.One person, Johnny Springsteen said: I wonder what the brake power is on that!Mark Barber said: Neigh gherkins.Dav Doc said: Horses are at drive-thrus all the time - only problem is they normally end up becoming the burgers themselves.Ben English said: Probably just wants a chicken Mc-neigh-get meal...And Shane Matthews simply added: Wow, awesome. Love this.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HorsesMcDonalds" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bride faints groom vomits defecated
story: Bride faints on groom, vomits and is defecated on during disastrous ceremonyBride Hollee Lynnea-Kolenda Darnell, , was hit with a sudden bout of sickness and swooned into her grooms arms during their outdoor ceremony in FloridaHollee Lynnea-Kolenda Darnell passed out, vomited and got pooped on during her vowsByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments An unlucky bride fainted on the groom before her nephew defecated on her wedding gown while she was vomiting. Hollee Lynnea-Kolenda Darnell, , who is from the US city of Minneapolis, Minnesota, got hitched recently to new hubby, Jackson, at a ceremony in Florida. Though the day started well, a sudden bout of sickness caused her to swoon into her concerned hubbyaposs arms during their vows.Her worried sweetheart can be heard asking whether she is okay as she comes back around. Hollee - dressed in a flowing, white bridal gown - shakes her head and stumbles over to the edge of the gazebo, and vomits over the side. In the clip, which has since gone viral, her caption read: I kept trying to tell my husband I didn’t feel good and he thought I was joking. The footage ended there, but the bride said there was still more bad wedding luck to come. In the caption she wrote: My baby nephew pooped on my dress right after while I was puking. Hollee later explained the reason for the sudden sickness. In a follow-up video she said she hadnapost eaten or drunk enough water during her big day, leaving her really dehydrated. She added: It was also Florida, and it was so hot and humid that day. We were drenched, it was so hot.Iaposm also prone to passing out, my doctor says I have low blood pressure and low iron. I guess I was just doomed from the start.  I wasnapost throwing up too much just because there wasnapost anything in my stomach so it wasnapost like the nasty, nasty throw up. My sister had a fan on my baby nephew, she came over to put that fan on me and as sheaposs holding my nephew, he starts pooping. And the poop goes down her arm onto my dress. The couple had already tied the knot at court a few hours before the outdoor do, which was just a small gathering with close friend and family.  For their honeymoon, the couple went to New York City straight after the winery ceremony. She managed to get some stunning wedding photos in the Big Apple by getting her dressed cleaned swtly after. She said: Now I have a story to tell at my nephew’s wedding someday. title: fedex delivery driver sacked dumping
story: FedEx delivery driver sacked for dumping hundreds of customers parcels down ravineWeeks before Christmas, the FedEx delivery driver hurled around  packages down the gorge in Blount County, Alabama, US - and police are probing the "awful act"FedEx were forced to send a number of trucks to collect the abandoned packages Image: Blount County Sherfs OfficeBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | comments A delivery driver who dumped hundreds of Christmas presents down a ravine has been sacked after being questioned by police.FedEx have fired the worker from Blount County, Alabama, US, for heaping around  parcels down the gorge in six separate trips.Police found the packages and hit out at the driver for committing an “awful” act just weeks before Christmas. Blount County Sherf’s Office said the boxes were “of assorted sizes”. They say they ask yet have no idea why the employee, who has not yet been named, dumped them at the busiest time of the year. Sherf Mark Moon believed the delivery driver went back and threw the packages from a van “at least six times”.  He explained that the boxes were found in a wooded area on private property. He said: “As of right now we are looking at around  inidual victims, some in Blount County some not, that investigators are attempting to work their cases. “We are in the process of contacting officials with FedEx so that they can investigate this situation and contact their customers.Photos posted on Facebook and twitter show abandoned boxes scattered on a steep ravine with several trucks lined up in the woods ready to collect them.  FedEx confirmed they had sent multiple trucks to recover the packages. In a statement they announced that the person involved was no longer working for the delivery giants. FedEx added it was cooperating with police on its investigation. “The security of our customers’ shipments is a top priority and we are committed to treating our customers’ packages with the utmost care,″ FedEx said. Where possible, recovered packages are being delivered to the intended recipients. In the event of a damaged shipment, we will make every effort to work with the affected shippers to reach a resolution. The company directed customers with any questions to track their shipments online.
