title: coronavirus in scotland track the spread in these charts and maps
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. title: coronavirus in scotland here are the key demographics
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: covid vaccine in scotland track the rollout progress with these charts
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: aberdeen grammar marr ali oconnor
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowNo matter how frustrating the Covid clerical fiasco has been, there is no excuse for taking it out on vaccination staff at clinics.They have worked beyond the call of duty during the pandemic and continue to be there to help us.Questions, however, must be asked over the management of the Covid booster programme.Senior NHS Highland and HSCP managers must bear responsibility for the needless mistakes, many of which a little local knowledge could have quickly rectied.We detected, in the response to our enquiries, a note of irritation at NHS staff time taken up addressing media questions as the confusion unfolded.The situation is entirely of NHS senior management#s making, and the media has every right to ask questions of a publicly-funded service on behalf of the people of Argyll and Bute.We hope and trust, however, that the admin problems have now been resolved.That aside, thank you to all the NHS staff helping each of us by delivering vital Covid booster jabs # it is genuinely appreciated while the virus remains a threat.And this Sunday at am, let#s think about others who made unimaginable sacrices on our behalf.Lest we forget.

title: battling star hold title favourites
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Red Star ed home with a point after a battling performance against league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie on Saturday November .Star stung the hosts at Cowan Park, Barrhead, with an excellent start to the match, forcing a succession of corners before the ever-dangerous Coll McCallum finished after an excellent delivery by Craig Aitken.The visitors doubled their lead after  minutes when Craig Aitken broke clear down the left and finished with an excellent effort into the goalkeeper’s far corner to put Star - ahead.Star were under pressure for much of the remainder of the half but always carried a threat on the break, with Stuart MacLean’s pace causing the home side no end of problems.Into the second half, Arthurlie forced their way back into the match and pulled a goal back after a rare defensive lapse by Star on  minutes. Star failed to clear the danger from a cross and the unfortunate Coll McCallum erted into his own net past Leon Murphy.The Arthurlie equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when winger Sean Ross cut inside before unleashing a spectacular effort into the top corner.The hosts would have been expected to go on and win the game from here but the Star defence remained well-organised and resolute and a fine goalkeeping performance from Leon Murphy ensured the Lochgilphead side ed home with a well-earned point.Star put their unbeaten league record on the line on Saturday November  when they welcome fellow Argyll side Cardross to the Joint Campus G. Kick-off pm.PIC:The SAFL Division One table after last weekend#s matches. no_aStar_LeagueTable

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 19 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: red star face busby in league
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowAfter last weekend#s SAFL Division One tie away to Claremont was postponed, Lochgilphead Red Star this weekend face Busby at the Ropework park.Star currently sit in the top half of the table, having played one or two games fewer than their rivals above them in what is shaping up to be a competitive league.The match on Saturday December  starts at pm, and a good home support at the Ropework would be welcome.A win for the Mid Argyll outfit would see them move up to third in the table.

title: co op defends argyll and bute pricing policy
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt is central to many rural communities, but the Co-op has faced recent criticism of its pricing and stocking policy in Argyll.What the Co-op does have in its favour is excellent local staff in these stores, but the cost and iety of goods has been questioned # something beyond the control of store staff.Peter Bates, deputy convenor of Tarbert and Skipness Community Council, has taken up the cause after noticing substantial dferences in the price among a iety of goods between Oban supermarkets and the Tarbert Co-op branch.On November  he wrote on the #All Things Tarbert# Facebook page: #The Co-op board and executive really need to have a hard think about their pricing policy, stocking policy and supply issues.#The price dferences between shops in Oban and the Co-op was made startlingly aware to me on our last shopping trip:#Honeydew melon # Oban £., Tarbert £.#Tarbert Co-op has destocked several items over the past year, but they are readily available on the Lochgilphead Co-op shelves. It is not #green# to have to do a -mile car journey for essentials.#The Co-op also seems to be replacing many branded items with their own products which are nowhere near as good.#He believes this policy is #pricing out rural living#, and continued: #It is particularly hard-hitting for those less mobile, non-car owners and the elderly.#Come on Co-op, a change needs to happen.#His post attracted a big response # with people in other parts of Argyll and Bute supporting his views.Mr Bates has since written directly to the Co-op, but emphasised: #The excellent hard-working management and staff at the Co-op in Tarbert are a big part of our community and are very helpful and kind. They have no control over pricing and stocking policy, which is decided by the board.#Stressing that the supermarket operates a UK pricing policy, a Co-op spokesperson said: #Co-op is committed to serving and supporting its rural communities, conveniently, including areas where other retailers often do not trade due to the increased operational costs.#Like all retailers, Co-op has experienced some patchy disruption to the availability of some products, and it is working with suppliers to re-stock as quickly as possible.#Alongside well-known brands, Co-op#s award-winning own-brand products provide shoppers with choice # delivering quality and value, while also enabling customers and community causes to unlock additional value and benefits through its membership programme.#Mr Bates added: #The Co-op bosses in Manchester need to realise that the Tarbert Co-op and others in rural locations are not convenience stores. These are often the only store for miles and are therefore leline stores.#If they do not understand this, then they do not understand the communities they are serving.#Speaking on Wednesday this week, Mr Bates said he had received no reply from Co-op management.He said ##apart from an automated receipt reply, I have heard nothing further. I intend to send the e-mails again.#PIC:Co-op acknowledged #patchy disruption to the availability of some products# but said Argyll store pricing policy is the same as across the UK. _acoopemptyshelvest-co-op-logo-no

title: see-live-rugby-region-weekend
story: A FULL-CARD of live rugby s to the region and beyond this weekend.On Saturdayin the Premiership Hawick host GHA, Selkirk are away at Musselburgh whilst Jed-Forest are at home to Edinburgh Accies.In the Tennents National League Division One Gala travel to Stirling to face the Wolves, Kelso host Cartha Queenrsquos Park at Poynder Park whilst Melrose are in the capital to face Heriotrsquos Blues.In the Tennents National League Division Two Peebles are away at Whitecraigs.In the Tennents National League Division Three Berwick are away to Greenock Wanderers.In East League One Duns are away to Linlithgow.In East League Two Hawick Linden face Corstorphine in Edinburgh.In East league Three Gala YM host Earlston in a Borders derby.In the Reserve East One Hawick Force host Biggar, Jed-Forest A are at home to Edinburgh accies and Selkirk A are away to Musselburgh A.In the Reserve League East Two, Gala A host Leith A, Melrose Storm are at home to Edinburgh Accies B, Peebles Reds host Watsonians B and Kelso Sharks are away to Linlithgow A,In the Semi-Junior Borders League Hawick Youth host Gala Wanderers, Kelso Harlequins are at home to Carlisle Colts, Melrose Wasps hosts Morpeth Colts and Peebles Colts are at home to Alnwick.On Sunday Kelso Ladies play Stewartry at Poynder Park.As always games are subject to late change so always check before going along.

title: mccallum-hoping-world-title-eliminator-vegas
story: Galashiels boxer John McCallumrsquos IBF Intercontinental Cruiserweight title fight against Kazakhstan fighter Issa Akberbayev at York Hall was postponed at the last minute.The fight had been scheduled for Friday  November but Akberbayev withdrew citing illness two days before.A previous fight between the pair was called off by Akberbayev due to Covid.A frantic search to find another opponent for the McCallum failed and he is now in talks about a world title eliminator in Las Vegas next month.A disappointed McCallum told the Border : ldquoThat fight was for meant to be for my dad Steven Robinson who is seriously ill with cancer in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital and that has been taken away.ldquoI had a massive support and many of them were spending the weekend in London.ldquoIrsquom really annoyed and it has even made me think of chucking it. The whole thing has been a massive disappointment. It wasnrsquot about belts or money it was for my dad and as soon as I found out I drove to Edinburgh to be with him.ldquoI donrsquot think Irsquoll be fighting Akberbayev again after the two call offs. This was an oral virus which meant he was unable to fly.ldquoIrsquove been asked to fight Andrew Tabiti who is in the Mayweather camp for a world title eliminator which would take place in Las Vegas on -December at the Mandalay Bay and Irsquom up for that. The Intercontinental belt is still vacant butthis comes off Irsquoll bypass that.ldquoI peaked for the Akberbayev so Irsquoll have a few days rest then get back in training at my local gym before heading to Vegas about five days before the fight. Irsquom in good shape so that should be OK.

title: date-announced-next-years-maroond-gala-festival
story: BUILDING on its success in , the Maroonrsquod@Gala sports and music festival willto Netherdale next year.The event will take place at the home of Gala Rugby, on Saturday, August , .Praised for its innovation and inclusivity, the inaugural edition of Maroonrsquod@Gala provided competition opportunities for primary school age rugby players under s under s under s senior and ladies sections and players with physical and learning disabilities.It also played host to football and running events.In addition to the showpiece sporting event ndash which culminated with the final of the famous Gala Sevens - there were live bands, street food, themed drinks areas and fun zones.Despite challenging weather conditions and the requirement to work in accordance with government coronavirus guidance, the free  event was attended by around ,-, people.It received positive feedback with participants, vendors and spectators stating their intention tofor future editions.Ian Dalgleish, the president of Gala RFC, said: ldquoThe Maroonrsquod@Gala concept has been very well received and the success of our inaugural event this summer, coupled with positive feedback and the continued support of our partners, has given us confidence to bring it back in .ldquoTogether, wersquore committed to creating a community event that local people want to be part of and to celebrate the proud sporting history of Gala Rugby, as well as to inspire our future stars."We also want to build on what we achieved this year and to extend the feel-good factor beyond the Netherdale site, maximising the positive economic impact in Galashiels town centre.Maroonrsquod@Gala was initially scheduled to take place in April  but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Further details will be announced in due course.

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: souters-appear-holiday-alley-web-tv
story: NINE Scottish country dancers from Selkirk have appeared on a lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that aired on Holiday Alley web-TV today As part of the Holiday Alley Festival held in the town of Selkirk Manitoba, Canada, residents of towns named Selkirk from around the world were invited to film themselves dancing.The Souters, who are all aged over  took up the challenge and their dance to the -bar reel lsquoDeil Amang the Tailorsrsquo impressed the judges.Margaret Pritchard told the Border : ldquoWe are all from the Selkirk Scottish Country Dance class and have been dancing together for a long time. We got permission to film our dance in front of the Mungo Park Court which was appropriate as itrsquos just across from the statue of Mungo Park.ldquoThe dance was filmed and sent away to the festival organisers and we just received an email back saying that they were delighted with it so we are all thrilled and looking forward to watching it later this month.The women who took part were Maureen Buckley, Shirley Brown, Freda Nicholson, Margaret Pritchard, Mary Harkness, Maureen Davidson, Olive Stillie, Wendy Boustead and Ros Roxburgh.

title: storm-arwen-borders-road-closures-outlined-council
story: A NUMBER of roads remain closed after Storm Arwen hit the Borders this weekend.Thousands of the regionrsquos residents have spent nights without powerfollowing damage caused by the weather.And Scottish Borders Council has confirmed that a number of routes are still affected.BerwickshireB - Charterhall - likely to remain closed for rest of weekB - Ayton to Eyemouth - likely to remain closed for rest of weekD  - Westloch Road, Coldingham - likely to remain closed for rest of weekC - Edrom to Blanerne - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEyemouth - High Street - buildings issueEyemouth - Victoria Road - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEyemouth - Paxton Terrace - buildings issueEyemouth - Albert Road - buildings issueOff B - Whitfield cottages - likely to remain closed for rest of weekCheviotB - Fans Farm Yarlside - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEildonD  - Ashiesteel to Craigmyle - likely to remain closed for rest of weekTweeddaleC - Tweedsmuir to Talla - likely to remain closed for rest of weekOn the closures, a council spokesperson said: ldquoSome other very minor routes may also be affected.ldquoPlease continue to drive with caution as even where trees have been cleared, there may be debris on next to the road.

title: msp-urges-bus-company-return-x95-service-hourly
story: SOUTH OF Scotland MPS Colin Symth has stepped up calls to reverse cuts to the X bus service which runs from Edinburgh to Carlisle servicing communities across Midlothian, the Borders, Dumfries and Galloway and Cumbria including Newtongrange, Hawick Galashiels and Langholm.The service now runs every two hour and Borders Buses say they have no current plans to reintroduce an hourly service due to a shortage of drivers across the country which they blame on lsquounprecedented delays in processing vocational driver licence applicationsrsquo.Sharon Morrison, communications director for Borders Buses, said: ldquoIn normal circumstances we have always responded positively to demand and requests for increased frequencies and journeys. Unfortunately, due to a driver and labour shortage across the industry and country respectively, we are unable to increase the frequency of our operation. We hope this changes over the coming months.ldquoWhilst the volumes of people travelling is down roughly % from  patronage levels, we welcome the continued support from the Scottish Government. Despite this much needed funding, the impact of Brexit, C, self-isolating and - most importantly - the unprecedented delays in processing vocational driver licence applications, continues to have a massive bearing on our service delivery.ldquoWe would also stress, unlike some operators across the UK, we are not cutting services and are operating all services registered. The is a huge testament to the hard work and effort of our Borders Buses team.Mr Smyth agreed about the backlog but also believes that the Scottish Government should have secured meaningful guarantees from bus firms that they would maintain services infor the pound.m of support given to companies during the pandemic.He said: ldquoThe UK Government need to do more by tackling the shocking backlog in processing driving licences and increasing availability of tests to ensure that when bus companies do decide to increase services they have the drivers to do so..removeldquoEveryone understands why companies reduced services when Covid hit, especially given the potential health impact on both passengers and drivers. It may also be some time before passenger numbers rise back to even close to pre-pandemic levels, but we will never get people back on our buseswe take those buses away.ldquoThe X is a crucial service that covers many communities across the South of Scotland and the lack of frequency simply means itrsquos just not an option anymore for people who want to use the bus.ldquoI have urged Borders Buses to reinstate this service to an hourly one. However, their decision not to so far highlights the failure of the Scottish Government to secure proper guarantees from bus firms that infor the tens of millions of pounds that was given to the sector during the pandemic, they should not be cutting services and we need to look again at how that support works.

title: jedburgh-pupils-waving-sanitary-products-like-flags-meeting-hears
story: BORDERS pupils using gender-neutral toilets have been ldquowaving sanitary products about like flags and urinating in sanitary bins, according to an elected official.As well as the reports of the incidents at Jedburgh Grammar School, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott says he has heard stories of girls at Kelso High School going an entire day without a toilet visit after refusing to use the unisex loos.But a Scottish Borders Councilspokesperson says that both schools have ldquono knowledge of these incidents taking place.A motion was put forward by Mr Scott at a full council meeting last week demanding the council to consult with pupils and teachers over plans to install gender-neutral toilets at the new Galashiels Academy and Peebles High buildings.:Storm Arwen: lsquoFurther strong winds expectedrsquo over next  hours, says councilAt Thursdayrsquos meeting, the independent representative said: ldquoYoung girls going through certain changes in their le are entitled to extra privacy as far as toilet facilities are concerned.ldquoThey should not have to share with teenage boys or men.On the alleged issues at the schools in Jedburgh and Kelso, Mr Scott added: ldquoThese young people need to feel safe and comfortable in their surroundings, and to be able to use the facilities on offer without embarrassment or anxiety, whether caused intentionally or otherwise.ldquoWhile Irsquom fully in agreement about providing support for minority groups, that support should be provided without the detriment to others.ldquoWhy is it not possible to have male, female and gender-neutral toilets which would cater for the needs of everyone Mr Scott called for a full consultation on the matter and for the council to publish the results.:Gamekeeper recklessly killed  protected birds on Borders estate, court hearsHe also advised discussions with the parents of primary school children due to attend the new campuses in the coming years..removeSeconding Mr Scottrsquos motion, independent Selkirkshire councillor Caroline Cochrane backed his calls for a consultation.ldquoIf wersquore saying that they [the pupils] are mature enough to share toilet facilities then they are mature enough to decide what they find acceptable and are comfortable with, she said.There has been much debate on the pros and cons of gender-neutral toilets.Those in favour of the unisex facilities say that they can help reduce bullying, as well as being more inclusive to the trans community and to disabled people with carers of the opposite sex.However, those against the loos say that they threaten the safety of women.

title: bench-memory-selkirk-singer-unveiled-home-town
story: DOZENS of people turned out to the unveiling of a commemorative bench in memory ofFrightened Rabbit frontman, Scott Hutchison in the grounds of Haining House on Saturday, November .The former stately home which was given over to the public to be used as an arts centre was chosen as the perfect location for the beautully crafted oak bench which has the words ldquoWhile Im alive, Irsquoll make tiny changes to the earth emblazoned across the front.These words were taken from the lyrics of Scotts song lsquoHead Rolls OffrsquoScott took his own le in May  after suffering from depression and a charity in his name was launched to raise awareness about children and young peoplersquos mental health issues.The bench was made by three trainee female carpenters, and was crowdfunded by fans with money left over from another bench that was situated in Kelvingrove Park in .Ade Cartwright, the organizer of the bench fundraiser, said in a statement: ldquoThis bench is for all those out there who have been touched by Scottrsquos lyrics and music, his humour and humanity. Itrsquos a place to put the headphones on and listen to his music and take a deep breath of fresh air, a place to sit down and have a good catch-up with friends, a place to celebrate Scottrsquos le and what he means to all of us. Also to just rest your weary legs, itrsquos a fair trek!To donate to the charity, visit https:tinychanges

title: langlee-coronavirus-pcr-test-site-depriving-residents
story: THE Bordersrsquo site for PCR coronavirus tests is lsquodeprivingrsquo residents of a vital community hub, a meeting has heard.The walk-through test site at Langlee Community Centre is operated by the UK Governmentrsquos Department of Health and Social Care.During a full council meeting last week, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked the council whether it would find a dferent site for the testing station after receiving concerns from a community group.Mr Scott said that the continued use of the centre by the NHS is ldquodenying the use of the large hall and cafeacute to the groups who normally use those facilities.:Peebles woman was found with large quantity of cocaine worth more than pound,Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar ndash the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport ndash said that the site has ldquohigh usage.ldquoThe UK Government has asked that the PCR test sites remain operational until March , he said. ldquoThe current lease expires in January .ldquoThe Langlee site is the only PCR site in the Borders. It has a high usage which is anticipated to increase over the winter period.ldquoIt is in a relatively central location within the most populated Borders locality. Five groups were displaced from Langlee, all five groups were offered alternative provision.Responding, Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoI appreciate the need to support the NHS in the early stages of this horrible pandemic but things have moved on now.ldquoThe other side of the coin is this centre in Langlee is in the middle of one of the areas that houses some of the poorest and socially deprived iniduals in the Borders.ldquoThis centre is vital in the maintenance of their mental health and wellbeing.:Man stole money from Borders busker after throwing bottle at wall, say policeldquoI donrsquot think itrsquos acceptable that this Langlee community is deprived of this centre for any longer than is necessary..removeAccording to Mr Scott, he has received correspondence from NHS Scotland stating that the ldquorequired facilities for a testing station are not overly prescriptive.Mr Edgar said that Scottish Borders Council officers are ldquoactively engaged in finding alternative sites.However, the independent councillor said that the requirements of any potential new site ndash including the need for safe queuing, separate entry and exit routes and sufficient toilet facilities ndash is making this dficult.He said that the old school buildings at council headquarters had been looked at but were discounted due to space and accessibility issues.Mr Edgar added that empty retail units in Galashiels had also been considered.PCR tests can also be accessed through mobile testing units and home test kits, according to NHS Borders.

title: galashiels-former-borders-college-campus-plans-revealed
story: PLANS for the former Borders College campus in Galashiels have been revealed.Eildon Housing has acquired the ldquokey site as part of plans to provide ldquomuch-needed high quality affordable rented homes.Nile Istephan, CEO of Eildon Housing, says the housing association is working closely with the council to produce a ldquodetailed proposal for the site.:Man stole money from Borders busker after throwing bottle at wall, say policeldquoWe have acquired the site of the former Borders College, on Melrose Road, Galashiels which has been lying vacant for many years now, he said. ldquoThis site offers a great opportunity for Eildon to provide much needed affordable homes to rent in a popular, central area of the town.Mr Istephan added: ldquoThis is a signicant regeneration site, and we will be able to provide a range of housing options to meet known local needs, as well helping the Borders meet sustainability and climate change targets. Our investment also generates high quality local training and employment opportunities.The former campus plans form a part of Eildonrsquos ldquorecord-breaking expansion of housing and care services in the Borders.Building work may not start until the summer of , according to the housing association.

title: peebles-charity-launches-text-campaign-childrens-clothes
story: A BORDERS charity has launched a fundraising text appeal to help it provide local youngsters with essential clothing.Peebles-based Tweed Togs has been operating since  to make high-quality, pre-loved clothing available for children aged  and under.And now the charity is running a lsquoWinter Wunder Wearrsquo campaign to raise money to buy essential garments ndash such as underwear and pyjamas ndash for youngsters across the Borders.Details of items needed are regularly posted on the charityrsquos Facebook page.Susan Walker, Tweed Togsrsquo chair, said: ldquoUsing our Facebook page to request specic donations of clothing is working really well.ldquoOur most urgent need is funding for underwear and pyjamas.ldquoEvery referral is provided with a set of new pants, socks and vests and as more and more requests have been made, Tweed Togs need to quickly replenish these stocks.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the charityrsquos ability to fundraise has been reduced.However, it received a grant from SPIFOX ndash an organisation which raises money for childrenrsquos causes in Scotland ndash but this money is due to run out.The charity says that since August demand for its services has ldquoincreased rapidly week on week as it has received referrals from more than  dferent agencies across the Borders.To date, it has provided clothing to more than  children around the region.Tweed Togsrsquo services are free and totally anonymous and recipients of the clothes receive their packages within  days of receipt of the referral.Referrals to Tweed Togs can be made by healthcare professionals, schools, charities, the Citizens Advice Bureau, churches and support groups.It offers seasonally appropriate clothing, as well as underwear, which is then packaged into gt bags for the youngsters.Due to limited storage space at its base in Peebles Business and Art Hub, Tweed Togs ensures any excess clothing donations avoid landfill and are reused or recycled..removeMs Walker said: ldquoThe generosity of local people and businesses is absolutely astounding.ldquoWe are hugely grateful to our volunteers and followers who give of their time and services freely and to those who take time to donate beautul pre loved clothes.To donate to the Winter Wunder Wear campaign, text PANTS to  to donate pound, or to donate pound text PJS to .For more information, including details of requested items, visit Tweed Togs Facebookpage.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. There are currently over  across Scotland and the network continues to grow.Officers also say that taking part in the lsquoYour Police Surveyrsquo is one way for people to express their views and needs.Responses to Your Police Survey helps officers identy and eliminate obstacles and barriers for anyone who needs them and they would encourage everyone to take part to influence policing in their area.Your Police Survey is available in easy read and British Sign Language formats.Take part here http:ow.ly BXwHPh

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: west-linton-host-first-live-coffee-concert
story: A BORDERS village is set to host its first live coffee concert.During the coronavirus pandemic the West Linton Village Centre hosted a number of virtual music events, however, the centre will now welcome a live audience for Twogether Duo.Twogether Duo, formed of Alena Bulatetskaya from Russia on classical accordion and Huixin Hu from China on violin, will perform a range of numbers, including classical pieces, folk songs, and Christmas favourites.And in the interval guests can enjoy a cup of coffee or tea with a choice of home-baked treats for free.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe Coffee Concerts series have been made possible courtesy of a grant awarded to the VC from the CAF Tourle Foundation and with the assistance of Live Music Now Scotland.Spaces for the Coffee Concert are limited, and tickets can be booked by emailing westlintonvillagecentre@gmail or by calling texting  . For those who are unable to attend in person, the performance will be streamed via Zoom. To register, click here.Twogether Duo will perform at West Linton Village Centre on Saturday, December  from -.pm.

title: ministers-want-industry-led-solution-give-musicians-streaming-money
story: The Government will change the law to make sure musicians get more money from streaming onlyan ldquoindustry-led solution cannot be found, a minister has said.Business minister George Freeman told MPs the Governmentrsquos first instinct was to ldquoavoid legislation, as he acknowledged there was a ldquoproblem of musicians not receiving a substantial cut of streaming revenues.His comments came as MPs debated the Bill, sponsored by Labour MP for Cardf West Kevin Brennan.vw,vw,px, px"Kevin Brennan with Rebecca Ferguson in Parliament Square The Private Memberrsquos Bill, which did not receive backing from the Government, sought to introduce a right to ldquoequitable remuneration for streaming income, where performers have a right to receive a share without reference to their label contracts.It would also give musicians more of a say over how their music is used, with MPs hearing that Dame Vera Lynn could have reclaimed ownership rights to her music, receiving royalties after Wersquoll Meet Again and other favourites experienced a revival in recent years.Mr Freeman told MPs: ldquoIf we can avoid legislation but solve the problem in some other way, thatrsquos our first instinct.ldquoBut indeed, I want to make very clearwe conclude that legislative changes are the only way to achieve what the House is looking for, then that is very much open to us.vw,vw,px, px"George Freeman ldquoWe want to work very closely with the industry, and let me just take this opportunity to make clear to the industry, who will be watching this closely, that we do think there is a problem, we want to make sure we get it right and we want to work with them to get the right measures in place.Labour MP Mr Brennan told MPs that ldquowonderful British artist Dame Vera would have been able to reclaim rights to her musichis proposals were made law.He later said: ldquoIf, after a period of  years, they are dissatisfied with the efforts being made by record labels or publishers ndash and this would apply to Dame Vera Lynn, I am glad to say, were she still with us ndashthey are dissatisfied with the efforts being made by record labels or publishers, musicians could give notice of their intention to reclaim their rights to exploit their music or transfer that right to another label or publisher who might do a better job than the existing one..removeHe was responding to Conservative MP Natalie Elphicke , who described Dame Vera as ldquoone of our most loved entertainers and icons across the country, adding: ldquoYet she found herself with a revival of some of her most famous and beloved songs, and not receiving royalties from a contract that was conceived and signed before the internet had even been considered and built.vw,vw,px, px"Dame Vera Lynn Mr Brennan insisted his Billrsquos efforts to remunerate musicians for streaming was ldquonot about anarchy in the UK, adding: ldquoThis Bill is about equity in the UK music industry.Conservative former cabinet minister Esther McVey gave her backing to the Bill, and said the taxpayer should have not picked up the bill for big labels who did not pay their artists ldquocorrectly during the pandemic.Ms McVey said: ldquoCovid shone a spotlight into this area. In the past, artists could go out and earn extra money through performing at live events. Not now, they couldnrsquot, and they would rely far more heavily on what was coming through from streaming.ldquoWhy should the taxpayer pick up the bill for these international giants who arenrsquot paying their contributors, creators, writers, correctly ldquoThat is wrong.A spokesperson for BPI, which represents record labels, said: ldquoDame Vera Lynn has received and continues to receive royalties for the success of Wersquoll Meet Again as well as all the recordings she made with Decca.ldquoIn fact, from  onwards and throughout her le, Decca and Dame Vera enjoyed a very close working relationship that continues to this day with her family and her estate.ldquoTogether, they have worked on a number of record breaking and chart topping releases..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Ministers want  uindustry-led u solution to give musicians more streaming money
